title: Expands the authority of the supreme court to hear election case disputes
summary: Expands the authority of the supreme court to hear disputes relating to proceedings involving special and general elections.

       Introduced  by  M.  of A. DESTITO, KAVANAGH -- read once and referred to
         the Committee on Election Law

       AN ACT to amend the election law, in relation to the jurisdiction of the
         supreme court to hear cases involving disputed results of general  and
         special elections

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Section 16-102 of the election law, as amended  by  chapter
    2  373  of  the laws of 1978, subdivision 2 as amended by chapter 79 of the
    3  laws of 1992 and subdivision 4 as added by chapter 135 of  the  laws  of
    4  1986, is amended to read as follows:
    5    S  16-102.  Proceedings  as  to designations and nominations, primary,
    6  SPECIAL AND GENERAL elections, etc. 1. The nomination or designation  of
    7  any candidate for any public office or party position or any independent
    8  nomination, or the holding of an uncontested primary election, by reason
    9  of  a  petition  for  an opportunity to ballot having been filed, or the
   10  election of any person to any party position OR  PUBLIC  OFFICE  AT  ANY
   11  PRIMARY,  SPECIAL  OR  GENERAL ELECTION may be contested in a proceeding
   12  instituted in the supreme court by any aggrieved candidate,  or  by  the
   13  chairman  of  any  party  committee  or by a person who shall have filed
   14  objections, as provided in this chapter, except that the chairman  of  a
   15  party committee may not bring a proceeding with respect to a designation
   16  or the holding of an otherwise uncontested primary.
   17    2.  A proceeding with respect to a petition shall be instituted within
   18  fourteen days after the last day to file the petition, or  within  three
   19  business  days  after the officer or board with whom or which such peti-
   20  tion was filed, makes a determination of invalidity with respect to such
   21  petition, whichever is later; except that a proceeding with respect to a
   22  petition for a village election  or  an  independent  nomination  for  a
   23  special  election  shall  be instituted within seven days after the last
   24  day to file the petition for such village election or independent  nomi-

    3  ity with respect to such petition, whichever is later. A proceeding with
    4  respect  to  a primary, SPECIAL OR GENERAL ELECTION, convention, meeting
    5  of a party committee, or caucus shall  be  instituted  within  ten  days
    6  after the holding of such [primary] ELECTION or convention or the filing
    7  of  the  certificate  of nominations made at such caucus or meeting of a
    8  party committee.
    9    3. The court may direct reassembling of any convention or the  holding
   10  of  a new primary election, or caucus where it finds there has been such
   11  fraud or irregularity as to render impossible a determination as to  who
   12  rightfully  was  nominated  or elected. IN THE CASE OF A PROCEEDING WITH
   13  RESPECT TO A SPECIAL OR GENERAL ELECTION, THE COURT SHALL FINALLY DETER-
   14  MINE WHO WAS RIGHTFULLY ELECTED; PROVIDED, HOWEVER,  THAT  WHEN  SUCH  A
   15  DETERMINATION  CANNOT BE MADE, THE COURT MAY DIRECT THE HOLDING OF A NEW
   16  ELECTION.
   17    4. A final order in any proceeding involving the names  of  candidates
   18  on  ballots or voting machines shall be made, if possible, at least five
   19  weeks before the day of the election at which  such  ballots  or  voting
   20  machines  are to be used, or if such proceeding is commenced within five
   21  weeks of such election, no later than the day following the day on which
   22  the case is heard.
   23    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.
